Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support schemas at runtime
Issues.Body:
Accounts for schemas in when validating properties in Ivy.

This PR resolves FW-819.

A couple of notes:
* I had to rework the test slightly, in order to have it fail when we expect it to. The one in master is passing since Ivy's validation runs during the update phase, rather than creation.
* I had to deviate from the design in FW-819 and not add an `enableSchema` instruction, because the schema is part of the `NgModule` scope, however the scope is only assigned to a component once all of the module's declarations have been resolved and some of them can be async. Instead, I opted to have the `schemas` on the component definition.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): support schemas at runtime" (#28637)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): compile pipe in context of ternary operator
Issues.Body:
Previously, it wasn't possible to compile template that contains pipe in context of ternary operator `{{ 1 ? 2 : 0 | myPipe }}` due to the error `Error: Illegal state: Pipes should have been converted into functions. Pipe: async`. See also https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/28587#issuecomment-461486458

This PR fixes a typo in expression parser so that pipes are correctly converted into functions.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): allow directive inheritance in strict mode
Issues.Body:
For TypeScript compilation units that have the "strictFunctionTypes"
option enabled, an error would be produced for Ivy's definition fields
in declaration files in the case of inheritance across directives or
pipes.

This change loosens the definition types to allow for subtypes of the
defined type where necessary.

A test package that has the "strict" option enabled verifies that we
won't regress in environments where strict type checking is enabled.

Fixes #28079

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): no longer re-export external symbols by default
Issues.Body:
**[NOTICE]**: Commit message is based on the fact that #28594 will be merged before this PR.

Blocked on #28594.

---

With #28594 we refactored the `@angular/compiler` API slightly to allow
opting out from external symbol re-exports which are enabled by default.

Since symbol re-exports only benefit projects which have a very strict
dependency enforcement, external symbols should not be re-exported
by default as this could grow the size of factory files and cause unexpected
behavior with Angular's AOT symbol resolving (e.g. see: #25644).

Additionally "ngtsc" also does not provide any way of using external symbol
re-exports, so this means that NGC partially matches the behavior of "ngtsc"
then (unless explicitly opted-out).

Internally at Google, symbol re-exports need to be still enabled since Google
has a very strict dependency enforcement (even of produced JavaScript output),
so the `ng_module` Bazel rule will enable the symbol re-exports by default when
running within Blaze.

Fixes #25644.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(compiler-cli): no longer re-export external symbols by default" (#28633)

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): allow non-unique #localRefs to be defined in a template
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change in Ivy we had strict check that disabled non-unique #localRefs usage within a given template. While this limitation was technically present in View Engine, in many cases View Engine neglected this restriction and as a result, some apps relied on a fact that multiple non-unique #localRefs can be defined and utilized to query elements via `@ViewChild(ren)` and `@ContentChild(ren)`. In order to provide better compatibility with View Engine, this commit removes existing restriction.

As a part of this commit, are few tests were added to verify VE and Ivy compatibility in most common use-cases where multiple non-unique #localRefs were used.


## PR Type

- [x] Feature

Issues.Title: ci: do not install firebase-tools without cache
Issues.Body:
Currently we install `firebase-tools` manually in the integration
tests run script. This is problematic because it means that we 
cannot cache `firebase-tools` properly and Yarn might time out
downloading this dependency. We can safely move this to the top
level `package.json` since Bazel now has a `.bazelignore` and since
we have a proper root level `package.json` cache that also works for
PRs (with fallback caching).

Note that the `.bazelignore` is relevant here because `firebase-tools`
has been mainly moved to the bash script because it broke some Bazel calls.

See 4f0cae067656fa4563417542297c67030d911a36.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: do not install firebase-tools without cache" (#28615)

Issues.Title: ci: add all required statuses to the requiredStatuses list for angular-robot
Issues.Body: Somehow the current list ommits quite a few important targets. Especially the cla and google3. This changes adds all the statuses that must always be present and green for this aggregate state expised as "ci/angular: merge status" to be green. This is the problem that this PR is attempting to solve: however after submitting this PR I realized that unless there is a google3 impacting change in the PR the bot doesn't push a commit status called "google3" so that status is currently only present for some changes. BLOCKING NOTE: That means that this PR can't be merged as is, as is blocked on a fix in the bot that always pushes the g3 status to all PR. If a PR does not have g3 impact, it should be marked as green with a status note stating "No google3 impact" - See: https://github.com/angular/github-robot/issues/40
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: add all required statuses to the requiredStatuses list for angular-robot" (#28613)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): enableIvy true value is an alias for ngtsc
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
Currently setting `enableIvy` to true runs a hybrid mode of `ngc` and `ngtsc`. This is counterintuitive given the name of the flag itself.


## What is the new behavior?
This PR makes the `true` value an alias for `ngtsc`. Effectively this removes the hybrid mode as well since there's no other way to enable it.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information
I'm not sure if the `true` option is currently used anywhere. 

@alxhub can you advise on:
- ways to test this change
- if there should be a migration path documented
- if a new value should be added to `enableIvy` to keep the existing hybrid behaviour (the current `true` value)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(compiler-cli): enableIvy true value is an alias for ngtsc" (#28616)

Issues.Title: "Too long with no output" error in integration_test job
Issues.Body:
The "integration_test" job seems to fail consistently in the "run_tests" step with a "Too long with no output" error:

See https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/194384

Debugged a bit with SSH and looks like the yarn install is hanging when it starts running the bazel  integration test:

```
#################################
Running integration test bazel
#################################
yarn install v1.13.0
[1/4] Resolving packages...
[2/4] Fetching packages...
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ""Too long with no output" error in integration_test job" (#28611)

Issues.Title: feat(router): add hash-based navigation option to setUpLocationSync
Issues.Body:
The `setUpLocationSync` function in @angular/router/upgrade didn't previously let you sync hash-based navigations. With this change, you can now pass an option to `setUpLocationSync` that will make sure location changes run in Angular in hash-based apps.

Fixes #24429 #21995
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(router): add hash-based navigation option to setUpLocationSync" (#28609)

Issues.Title: Add support for generating files on secondary entry points (sub packages)
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Creating a [secondary entry point](https://github.com/ng-packagr/ng-packagr/blob/master/docs/secondary-entrypoints.md), like testing, by hand isn't an issue on its own, but using the CLI for generating files for it, is. Whenever I try to generate a file for it, I need to be on the folder or write something like `ng g c ../../testing/src/lib/my-comp --project my-lib`.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I've imagined adding a `--project` flag to `ng generate library` to generate a secondary entry point:
`ng g lib testing --project my-lib`

The structure would be something like below:
```
my-lib
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
|   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ lib
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ testing
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
    |   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib
    |   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ public_api.ts
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json
```

The command would also add a property, like `entries`, on _angular.json_ library configuration, holding the secondary entry point path. We would need this property for when generating other files, like the following:
`ng g c my-comp --project my-lib/testing`

### Describe alternatives you've considered
We could have a new generation schematic for secondary entry points or a property to add the reference path on _angular.json_ manually.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for generating files on secondary entry points (sub packages)" (#13633)

Issues.Title: Wrong SockJS Host validation with Reverse Proxy
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

Angular CLI version : 7.2.3

### Command (mark with an `x`)

```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Is this a regression?

I don't know

### Description

When using "ng serve" behind a reverse proxy on a sub-path, the SockJS Server throws 400 errors because it fails to validate the Host/Origin header.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

I want to have my application served on my workstation at `http://dev.local/common-demo`

1. Create a new Angular CLI project
2. Configure the `serve` task in `angular.json` with
```json
            "host": "localhost",
            "port": 9038,
            "publicHost": "dev.local/common-demo/sockjs-node",
            "baseHref": "/common-demo/",
            "servePath": "/"
```
3. Configure you workstation reverse proxy with (here Apache is used)
```
ProxyPass /common-demo http://localhost:9038
ProxyPassReverse /common-demo http://localhost:9038
```

## üî• Exception or Error

Chrome console shows :

```
WebSocket connection to 'ws://dev.local/common-demo/sockjs-node/287/kbmqffv3/websocket' failed: Error during WebSocket handshake: Unexpected response code: 400

Invalid Host/Origin header

[WDS] Disconnected!
```

**Notes**

If I set `disableHostCheck` to `true`, it works, but I don't want to.

If I set `publicHost` to `dev.local` the app tries to connect to `ws://dev.local/sockjs-node` which is not valid as it ignores the `baseHref`.

The `servePath` needs to be `/` as the app is served at the root of `localhost:9038` (by default `servePath` inherits from `baseHref` but the sub-path is handled by the Reverse Proxy in my setup).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong SockJS Host validation with Reverse Proxy" (#13627)

# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
When setting "es5BrowserSupport": true in angular.json I get errors in IE 11 because it does not recognize .includes()
`TypeError: Object doesn't support property or method 'includes'`

This issue below gave the original workaround, perhaps now that it is in a conditional polyfill we can add it by default.
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/4128

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add the following polyfill to the Conditional ES5 Browser Polyfill so that .includes() works with IE 11
`import 'core-js/es7/array';`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I can keep `import 'core-js/es7/array';` in the main polyfill file, but it is not needed by other browsers

Issues.Title: Bug: cannot drop in connected cdkDropList inside element that has a ngIf
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

If a cdkDropList is inside an html element that has a ngIf, when the ngIf is at true state, you can drop elements inside the drop list if it is correctly connected to the origin list.

#### What is the current behavior?

You can't.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-drag-and-drop-bug).

As you can see, there are event handlers in cdk-drag-drop-connected-sorting-example so that the second-component's drop list container is visible only when you are dragging an element.
If you drag an element from the first list, you can't drop it in the second one, but if you remove the ngIf in second-component, you will be able to. There is no wiring for drop events, however you can see if you can drop (or not) as the list splits (or not) to leave space for the new element.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

I am running Angular 7.2.2, CDK 7.3.0, TypeScript 3.2.4, I have reproduced the issue on Firefox 65 and Chrome 71 on Ubuntu 18.04.1.

#### Is there anything else we should know?

This issue seems related to #13998, as you can see, I was careful to use string ids like said.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bug: cannot drop in connected cdkDropList inside element that has a ngIf" (#15139)

When the value changes quickly (about once every 200 ms), the progress bar becomes choppy and appears to even slightly regress.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Using the determinate progress bar, change the value quickly, at about once every 200ms. Example stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-eq4b5m

"@angular/core": "7.2.4",
"@angular/material": "7.3.1",

Chrome 72

Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Current [DragDropModule](https://material.angular.io/cdk/drag-drop/overview) does offer nice dragging effects but I can't find a way to export css styling that the module has changed over dragging. 

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
The reason to export this is to get information about the previous drag so that event browser hits refreshing, user can still have their current dragging based on data saved in server side

[DrapDrop Service](https://material.angular.io/cdk/drag-drop/api) offers create drag element when app is running. It's recommended to have a method inside this Service to export css value changed.

Issues.Title: LiveAnnouncer should have a global duration to remove the text
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

2. LiveAnnouncer.annouce(text)
3. the text is removed from DOM after global duration.


#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
When I open a MatDialog, I use screen reader(Voice Over) VO plus left arrow to do linear navigation. When I come to the beginning of dialog, I shouldn't be able to navigate to anywhere. However, I navigated to the DOM for LiveAnnouncer if LiveAnnoucer is used once.

I can use announce(text, duration) to work around this. This requires a duration for every announce call.


#### Is there anything else we should know?

Issues.Title: test(autocomplete): rework brittle tests
Issues.Body:
Reworks three brittle tests for the autocomplete component.

Two of them will fail in Ivy, because they depend on an implementation detail in how `DebugNode.query` works in `ViewEngine`.

The other reworked test depends on static queries which haven't been implemented in Ivy. The reason this test is being reworked, rather than waiting for a fix from core, is that it's there to specifically test an error that was caused by weird ViewEngine behavior. This behavior will no longer be possible in Ivy.

Issues.Title: icon's unit tests triggering warn logs about fake paths
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Suppressing the warning to not pollute the logs, similar to how you treat other annoying logs in  [icon.spec.ts:473](https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/master/src/lib/icon/icon.spec.ts#L475)

Please elaborate how to disable that log.

#### What is the current behavior?
When running the unit tests, I get this in my logs:
```bash
07 02 2019 17:10:06.341:WARN [web-server]: 404: /fake-path
07 02 2019 17:10:06.374:WARN [web-server]: 404: /another-fake-path
07 02 2019 17:10:06.410:WARN [web-server]: 404: /different-path
```
It is really annoying to get this logged in the middle of all successful tests.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Run the unit tests in `src/lib/icon/icon.spec.ts`


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Current (7.3) and 7.2

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Using `spyOn(console, 'warn')` didn't suppress the warning message.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "icon's unit tests triggering warn logs about fake paths" (#15113)
